factoid: Prince Andrew arrived at Tsárevo-Zaymíshche on the same day and hour that Kutúzov was reviewing troops for the first time.
Prince Andrew stopped in the village at the priest’s house.
The commander in chief’s carriage stood in front of the priest’s house.
Prince Andrew sat down on the bench at the gate awaiting his Serene Highness, as everyone now called Kutúzov.
From the field beyond the village came sounds of regimental music.
From the field beyond the village came the roar of many voices shouting “Hurrah!” to the new commander in chief.
Two orderlies, a courier, and a major-domo stood near by, some ten paces from Prince Andrew, availing themselves of Kutúzov’s absence and of the fine weather.
A short, swarthy lieutenant colonel of hussars with thick mustaches and whiskers rode up to the gate.
The lieutenant colonel of hussars glancing at Prince Andrew inquired whether his Serene Highness was putting up there and whether he would soon be back.
Prince Andrew replied that he was not on his Serene Highness’ staff but was himself a new arrival.
The lieutenant colonel of hussars turned to a smart orderly.
The smart orderly replied: "What? His Serene Highness? I expect he’ll be here soon. What do you want?"
The lieutenant colonel of hussars smiled beneath his mustache at the orderly’s tone, dismounted, gave his horse to a dispatch runner, and approached Bolkónski with a slight bow.
Bolkónski made room for the lieutenant colonel of hussars on the bench and the lieutenant colonel sat down beside him.
Bolkónski asked Prince Andrew if he was also waiting for the commander in chief.
Prince Andrew replied that he had taken part in the retreat and lost all he held dear, including the estate and home of his birth, and that his father died of grief.
Prince Andrew said he belongs to the province of Smolénsk.
Bolkónski said: "Ah? You’re Prince Bolkónski? Very glad to make your acquaintance! I’m Lieutenant Colonel Denísov, better known as ‘Váska’."
Lieutenant Colonel Denísov pressed Prince Andrew’s hand and looked into his face with particular kindly attention.

Lieutenant Colonel Denísov said: "Yes, I heard," and added: "Yes, it’s Scythian warfare. It’s all very well—only not for those who get it in the neck. So you are Prince Andrew Bolkónski?" He swayed his head.
Lieutenant Colonel Denísov repeated: "Very pleased, Prince, to make your acquaintance!"
Prince Andrew knew Lieutenant Colonel Denísov from what Natásha had told him of her first suitor.
Prince Andrew had received new impressions: the retreat from Smolénsk, his visit to Bald Hills, and the recent news of his father’s death.
Lieutenant Colonel Denísov had memories of a distant romantic past after supper and Natásha’s singing.
Lieutenant Colonel Denísov had proposed to a little girl of fifteen without realizing what he was doing.
Lieutenant Colonel Denísov had devised a plan of campaign while serving at outposts during the retreat.
Lieutenant Colonel Denísov had proposed that plan to Barclay de Tolly and now wished to propose it to Kutúzov.
The plan was based on the fact that the French line of operation was too extended.
The plan proposed attacking the French line of communication instead of or concurrently with action on the front to bar the advance of the French.
Lieutenant Colonel Denísov began explaining his plan to Prince Andrew.
